history.content:
EECS C106A is intro to robotics so I think that speaks for itself. You can go on to take 106B right after. Other classes that might be relevant are EECS 149, EE 192, etc.

And yes, it obviously satisfies an EECS upper division course, what makes you think otherwise?

--------------------

Another option you may be interested in is EEC128, which is on Feedback Control Systems. It's a little more directly connected to the concept of signals and systems and artificial intelligence than 106A since it covers the theory of control systems more throughly, but both are good courses to take (also, 106A can only be taken in the fall while 128 can be taken either semester, so take that into consideration as well).

---

As far as I have heard, 106A does not go into enough depth beyond the labs (which are interesting) to be truly integral, and is more like a survey course for an introduction to robotics. 128 is much more relevant.

EECS C106A is intro to robotics so I think that speaks for itself. You can go on to take 106B right after. Other classes that might be relevant are EECS 149, EE 192, etc.


And yes, it obviously satisfies an EECS upper division course, what makes you think otherwise?


--------------------


Another option you may be interested in is EEC128, which is on Feedback Control Systems. It's a little more directly connected to the concept of signals and systems and artificial intelligence than 106A since it covers the theory of control systems more throughly, but both are good courses to take (also, 106A can only be taken in the fall while 128 can be taken either semester, so take that into consideration as well).

EECS C106A is intro to robotics so I think that speaks for itself. You can go on to take 106B right after. Other classes that might be relevant are EECS 149, EE 192, etc.

And yes, it obviously satisfies an EECS upper division course, what makes you think otherwise?

I just completed CS188 and EE120 this semester. I plan on taking CS 189 this upcoming fall, and I'm interested in taking a robotics course to go hand in hand with it. Do you guys have any suggestions? I'm currently thinking about EECS C106A, but I'm not entirely sure if this class satisfies as an EECS upper division course or even if it's the best option to take. Any advice is appreciated.
history.subject: Robotics Course
